questions.text: A patient, who is a known case of secondary Hyperparathyroidism, came to the surgery OPD with the following lesion. He was immediately started on medical management and then taken for urgent surgery. What is the most suitable surgical option for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Total Parathyroidectomy with Transcervical Thymectomy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Total Parathyroidectomy with Transcervical Thymectomy The image given is that of Calciphylaxis or Calcific Uremic Arteriolopathy. It is characterized by painful violaceous skin lesions with associated ulceration, ischemia, necrosis, and eschar formation. An urgent parathyroidectomy has been shown to decrease pain, improve wound healing and reduce the risk of amputation in these patients. It has also been associated with an increase in median survival. Because of the high mortality associated with calciphylaxis (87%) and the potential for progression after subtotal parathyroidectomy , total parathyroidectomy with trans-cervical thymectomy is the preferred surgical option.

Highyeild:

Calciphylaxis causes painful skin lesions with ulceration, necrosis, and eschar formation. Patients with calciphylaxis may develop non-healing wounds with skin necrosis and risk complications such as gangrene, sepsis, and death. Mortality rates are high, ranging from 50% to 80%. The causes : medically-refractory hyperphosphatemia, a high calcium-phosphate product, high PTH levels, use of warfarin, protein C and protein S deficiency, and other causes of thrombophilia. A diagnosis is made in patients with chronic kidney disease and secondary HPT who have painful, violaceous, tender skin lesions and a skin biopsy showing vascular and extravascular calcifications without vasculitis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Subtotal parathyroidectomy is not done, as progression after it can be fatal. Option: B . Total parathyroidectomy with autologous graft is done in cases of secondary HPT . But it is paired with thymectomy in all cases. Option: D. Subtotal parathyroidectomy is not done, as progression after it can be fatal.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient, with chronic renal disease, hypocalcemia, with elevated PTH. Patient has a high serum phosphate and a low vitamin D level. The definitive treatment for this condition is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Renal Transplant Treatment of Secondary Hyperparathyroidism has changed radically with the introduction of Calcimimetic drugs, such as cinacalcet. Calcimimetics alter the set point of the CaSR, thereby reducing the constant stimulation of the parathyroid glands and lowering the PTH level. The case scenario described is that of secondary hyperparathyroidism. Renal transplantation remains the only definite treatment for secondary hyperparathyroidism . Other treatments act as a bridge to provide symptom relief. Calcium Supplementation Vitamin D Supplementation Phosphate Binder Calcimimetic Drug Surgical intervention ( Parathyroidectomy )

Highyeild:

Renal transplantation is the only definitive treatment for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Standard management includes calcium and vitamin D replacement, phosphate binders, and reduction of phosphate levels. Calcimimetic drugs like cinacalcet can lower PTH levels by altering the calcium-sensing receptor set point. Surgery options include subtotal parathyroidectomy and total parathyroidectomy with or without autograft.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Subtotal parathyroidectomy is where three and a half parathyroid glands are excised, with the remnant being marked with a non-absorbable stitch to facilitate identification in the event of recurrent disease. Option: B. Total parathyroidectomy with a forearm autograft involves removal of all parathyroid tissue in the neck, with reimplantation of a small amount of morcellated tissue within a pocket formed in the brachioradialis muscle. Option: C. Renal transplantation remains the only definite treatment for secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Extraedge:

Cryopreservation should be done in significant hypocalcemia. Subtotal parathyroidectomy and total parathyroidectomy are the most widely accepted.

questions.text: A patient was found to have hypocalcemia with elevated PTH and high serum phosphate levels. All of the following are the PRIMARY cause for this condition, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Parathyroid Adenoma Parathyroid Adenoma is a cause of Primary Hyperparathyroidism, which generally has HIGH serum Calcium, HIGH PTH, and LOW serum Phosphate levels. The case described is most likely that of Secondary Hyperparathyroidism. Parathyroid Adenoma is a cause of Primary Hyperparathyroidism, which generally has HIGH serum Calcium, HIGH PTH, and LOW serum Phosphate levels. Primary Causes of Secondary Hyperparathyroidism are: Chronic Kidney Disease (renal hyperparathyroidism), Gastrointestinal MALABSORPTION, Vitamin D deficiency, Liver Disease, or Chronic Lithium usage

Highyeild:

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is primarily due to chronic kidney disease. It is associated with parathyroid hyperplasia. Diagnosis is made biochemically with low/normal calcium and high PTH. High phosphate and low vitamin D levels are seen.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Secondary Hyperparathyroidism occurs primarily as a result of chronic kidney disease and is therefore referred to as renal hyperparathyroidism. Option: C. Intestinal Malabsorption can cause Secondary Hyperparathyroidism. Option: D. Vitamin D3 Deficiency can cause Secondary Hyperparathyroidism.

Extraedge:

Renal transplantation is the main treatment, and medical management with replacements and binders is a bridge to transplantation. Calcimimetics reduce the need for surgery. Subtotal parathyroidectomy is the preferred surgery.

questions.text: A known case of SECONDARY HYPERPARATHYROIDISM on medical management was taken up for surgery. All of the following can be an indication for this EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Severely impaired quality of life due to either SHPT or intolerance to Calcimimetics.

options.label: B
options.text: PERSISTENT or RECURRENT disease, the origin of which cannot be elucidated.

options.label: C
options.text: When SHPT is refractory to vitamin D replacement or vitamin D analogs and prolonged survival is anticipated.

options.label: D
options.text: When sufficient reduction in parathyroid hormone cannot be achieved with the use of Calcimimetics.

questions.correct_answer: B. PERSISTENT or RECURRENT disease, the origin of which cannot be elucidated.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PERSISTENT or RECURRENT disease, the origin of which cannot be elucidated. In case of PERSISTENT or RECURRENT disease, the origin of which cannot be elucidated, surgical management should be avoided. PROPOSED INDICATIONS FOR SURGICAL MANAGEMENT OF SECONDARY HYPERPARATHYROIDISM (SHPT) IN THE ERA OF CALCIMIMETICS. When SHPT is refractory to vitamin D replacement or vitamin D analogues and prolonged survival is anticipated. Severely impaired quality of life due to either SHPT or intolerance to Calcimimetics. When sufficient reduction in parathyroid hormone cannot be achieved with use of Calcimimetics. Thyroid surgery is also required (thyroid carcinoma)

Highyeild:

Indications for surgical management The surgery is needed when SHPT is refractory to vitamin D replacement or analogs. Severe impairment of quality of life or intolerance to calcimimetics can also warrant surgery. Surgery is needed when calcimimetics cannot achieve sufficient reduction in PTH. Thyroid surgery is also required when there is thyroid carcinoma.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A. Severely impaired quality of life due to either SHPT or intolerance to Calcimimetics is an indication for Surgery. Option C. Surgery is indicated when SHPT is refractory to vitamin D replacement or vitamin D analogs and prolonged survival is anticipated. Option D. Surgery is indicated when sufficient reduction in parathyroid hormone cannot be achieved with the use of Calcimimetics.

Extraedge:

Surgical intervention leads to a dramatic response. Biochemical parameters improve immediately and can last up to 3 years post-surgery. Patients report subjective improvements in symptoms such as bone pain, pruritus, fatigue, and depression. Bone metabolism improves, with about a 10% increase in trabecular bone and immediate suppression of bone resorption and acceleration of new bone formation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient, who underwent a renal transplant for treatment of Secondary Hyperparathyroidism, was found to have persistent autonomous hypercalcemic hyperparathyroidism on follow-up. The following causes can all cause this to happen, EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: Slow involution of enlarged Parathyroid Glands.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase Calcitriol Levels Post-Transplant. The case describes is that of Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism. Tertiary hyperparathyroidism is a persistent autonomous hypercalcemic hyperparathyroidism occurring after kidney transplantation Insufficient calcitriol conversion by the transplanted kidney can Lead to Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism. Calcitriol increase causes PTH to drop & deficiency leads to Hyperparathyroidism. A number of proposed factors may prevent the Iinvolution of the hyperplastic parathyroid glands following treatment of the underlying renal impairment: These include: Impaired graft function, Non-suppressible PTH secretion, Slow involution of enlarged Parathyroid glands, or Insufficient calcitriol conversion by the transplanted kidney.

Highyeild:

Tertiary hyperparathyroidism occurs after kidney transplantation Hyperplastic parathyroid glands may not involute after renal impairment resolution Factors include : impaired graft function, non-suppressible PTH secretion, slow involution, or insufcient calcitriol conversion Results in persistent autonomous hypercalcemia hyperparathyroidism

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Non-suppressible PTH secretion can lead to Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism Option: B. Slow involution of enlarged Parathyroid Glands can lead to Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism Option: D. Impaired graft function can lead to Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism

Extraedge:

Calcimimetics in tertiary hyperparathyroidism are controversial and not approved. Surgery is the definitive management strategy. Subtotal or total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation are acceptable options. Gland volume left approximately four times normal to minimize complications. Total parathyroidectomy without autograft is not an option due to persistent hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man, who underwent a Renal Transplant for treatment of Secondary Hyperparathyroidism, was found to have elevated serum calcium, elevated PTH, and reduced PHOSPHATE on follow-up 1-year post renal transplantation. What is the next course of treatment that can be offered to the patient in case of the progression of symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sub-Total Parathyroidectomy The biochemical diagnosis of Tertiary hyperparathyroidism is confirmed by an elevated total or ionized calcium, with an associated elevated or unsuppressed PTH and a reduced phosphate occurring at least 1-year post renal transplantation. The use of Calcimimetics in Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism remains controversial and has not been approved for this indication. The majority of endocrine surgeons will opt for a Subtotal Parathyroidectomy.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Total parathyroidectomy without an autograft is not a treatment option due to the postoperative and persistent difficulties in managing the associated hypocalcemia. Option: C . Second Renal Transplant is not an option required for treatment, as the Pathology is in Parathyroid Gland. Option: D . The use of Calcimimetics in Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism has not been approved.

Extraedge:

Calcimimetics in tertiary hyperparathyroidism are controversial and not approved. Surgery is the definitive management strategy. Subtotal or total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation are acceptable options. Gland volume left approximately four times normal to minimize complications. Total parathyroidectomy without autograft is not an option due to persistent hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A known case of Hypertension, after surgery for Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism, started exhibiting the following sign. What part of the treatment can lead to this?

options.label: B
options.text: Hypercalcemia following surgery due to recurrence.

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperkalemia due to Blood Pressure Medications.

questions.correct_answer: A. Hypocalcemia due to Total Parathyroidectomy.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypocalcemia due to Total Parathyroidectomy. A complication after Total Parathyroidectomy is Hypocalcemia. Most patients with postoperative hypocalcemia can be treated with Oral Calcium and Vitamin D supplements. Physical examination in hypocalcemia reveals: POSITIVE Chvostek’s sign, which is a contraction of facial muscles elicited by tapping on the facial nerve anterior to the ear. POSITIVE Trousseau’s Sign (image below) is a carpopedal spasm that is elicited by occluding blood flow to the forearm with a blood pressure cuff for 2–3 minutes.

Highyeild:

Cause of morbidity and mortality: Hypercalcaemia from PTH secretion. Treatment goal: Control hypercalcemia and remove carcinoma. Surgery is the main treatment for primary and locally recurrent diseases. Complete resection is important to prevent seeding and recurrence. En bloc resection, associated thyroid lobectomy, and central neck dissection are controversial.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Image shows Positive Chvostek's sign due to Hypocalcemia after Total Parathyroidectomy. OPTION B. Hypercalcemia doesn't cause Chvostek's sign Option: C. Hyperkalemia is raised Potassium in the It causes ECG changes. Option: D. Phosphate levels reduce to normal after transplant in Secondary HPT. Hypoparathyroidism as a complication of Parathyroidectomy causes Hypocalcemia.

Extraedge:

For prolonged or permanent hypocalcemia, start oral calcium with vitamin D immediately after surgery.
